text: I think that creating something like
Jack in the beanock with the ability to
climb your way into heaven is probably
still maybe a hundred years away however
we're making enormous inroads with
carbon nanot tubes and graphine ever
since the 1800s we knew that a space
elevator was physically possible if we
could create a substance that was
stronger than steel well now we have
such a substance these are carbon nanot
tubes and graphine
graphine is the hardest substance known
to science on the entire planet Earth
graphine is so strong that you can take
an elephant put the elephant on a pencil
balance the pencil on a sheet of
graphine and graphine will not tear well
if graphine is so powerful then why
can't we make this ladder to the Stars
the problem is strictly technical the
largest amount of pure carbon nitudes
and graphine that we can make in the
laboratory is about that big we need
thousands of miles of pure Cable in
order to create a space elevator the
problem with going to the stars is only
the first few hundred miles if you can
negotiate the first few hundred miles
and get off the gravitational well of
the planet Earth you're well on your way
to going to the Stars themselves that's
why a space elevator could literally
revolutionize space travel however the
technical problems are still enormous
satellites travel at 18,000 mph the
space elevator will probably not sustain
a direct hit with a satellite going at
18,000 mph and what happens in case of a
monsoon or a hurricane on the planet
Earth you would want to Anchor the space
elevator to some point on the Earth but
it has to be flexible again because what
happens when a hurricane rips right
through your territory and perhaps rips
the space elevator so there are a lot of
technical questions that still have to
be addressed but in principle a space
elevator is within the laws of
physics
